questions.text: Which attribute accurately describes myosin within muscle fibers? (NEET PG 2016)

options.label: B
options.text: Covers the active site on actin

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Myosin forms the thick filaments in muscle and possesses ATPase activity in its globular head region. The myosin head contains both an actin-binding site and a catalytic site that hydrolyzes ATP. This ATPase activity is essential for the power stroke during muscle contraction, as ATP hydrolysis provides the energy needed for the conformational change in the myosin head that generates force.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a. Component of thin filaments : Myosin constitutes the thick filaments, not the thin filaments. The thin filaments are composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin. Option b. Covers the active site on actin : This is the function of tropomyosin, not myosin. Tropomyosin covers the myosin-binding sites on actin during muscle relaxation, and is displaced when calcium binds to troponin C. Option d. Calcium-binding protein : Calcium binding is the function of troponin C, not myosin. Troponin C contains specific binding sites for calcium that initiate the contractile process.
  • • Option a. Component of thin filaments : Myosin constitutes the thick filaments, not the thin filaments. The thin filaments are composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.
  • • Option a. Component of thin filaments
  • • Option b. Covers the active site on actin : This is the function of tropomyosin, not myosin. Tropomyosin covers the myosin-binding sites on actin during muscle relaxation, and is displaced when calcium binds to troponin C.
  • • Option b. Covers the active site on actin
  • • Option d. Calcium-binding protein : Calcium binding is the function of troponin C, not myosin. Troponin C contains specific binding sites for calcium that initiate the contractile process.
  • • Option d. Calcium-binding protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myosin's ATPase activity is fundamental to muscle contraction as it hydrolyzes ATP to generate the energy needed for the power stroke, which creates movement by changing the angle of the myosin head while attached to actin.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest pH? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pancreatic juice has a pH of 8-8.3 , making it the most alkaline (highest pH) among the given options. Pancreatic juice contains high concentrations of bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻), which is secreted in response to secretin. In fact, the maximum HCO₃⁻ secretion in the GI tract occurs in the pancreas, contributing to its high alkalinity.
  • • 8-8.3
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastric juice - Has a pH of 1.2-3, making it highly acidic due to the secretion of HCl by parietal cells. This is the most acidic secretion in the GI tract. Option B. Bile - While bile is alkaline in nature and contains bicarbonate, its pH is not as high as pancreatic juice. Bile serves as an excretory fluid and aids in fat emulsification. Option D. Saliva - Has a pH of 6-7, making it slightly acidic to neutral. While it contains some bicarbonate, it's not as alkaline as pancreatic juice.
  • • Option A. Gastric juice - Has a pH of 1.2-3, making it highly acidic due to the secretion of HCl by parietal cells. This is the most acidic secretion in the GI tract.
  • • Option A. Gastric juice
  • • Option B. Bile - While bile is alkaline in nature and contains bicarbonate, its pH is not as high as pancreatic juice. Bile serves as an excretory fluid and aids in fat emulsification.
  • • Option B. Bile
  • • Option D. Saliva - Has a pH of 6-7, making it slightly acidic to neutral. While it contains some bicarbonate, it's not as alkaline as pancreatic juice.
  • • Option D. Saliva

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pancreatic juice has the highest pH (8-8.3) among major GI secretions due to its high bicarbonate content, which is essential for neutralizing acidic chyme from the stomach to provide the optimal pH for pancreatic enzymes to function.

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with low free T4. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH and low free T4 levels, indicating a failure of the thyroid gland itself to produce sufficient hormones.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except? ( NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Bronchodilation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Contrary to bronchodilation, ET-1 actually causes bronchoconstriction in the lungs, mediated through ET-B receptors. This makes it detrimental in respiratory pathologies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Vasoconstriction : Correct and a well-documented action of ET-1.
  • • Option B. Vasoconstriction
  • • Option C. Decreased GFR : Correct, as ET-1 affects renal blood flow and filtration.
  • • Option C. Decreased GFR
  • • Option D. Has inotropic effect : Correct, ET-1 increases the force of heart contractions.
  • • Option D. Has inotropic effect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)
  • ➤ Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)
  • ➤ On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension. In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors) In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB). In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon). Platelet activation Closure of ductus arteriosus. Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.
  • ➤ On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension
  • ➤ On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy
  • ➤ In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension.
  • ➤ In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors)
  • ➤ In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).
  • ➤ In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon).
  • ➤ Platelet activation
  • ➤ Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • ➤ Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and dyspnea. A diagnosis of cardiac tamponade is considered. Which of the following changes in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is most indicative of cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Y descent is blunted/absent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cardiac tamponade, the Y descent on the jugular venous pressure waveform is blunted or absent due to restricted right ventricular filling during diastole.

questions.text: Assertion : Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions. Reason : Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reasons is independently a false statement.

options.label: B
options.text: The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.

options.label: C
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: D
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

questions.correct_answer: C. Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane. The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.
  • ➤ Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • ➤ The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

questions.text: "a" wave on JVP is for: ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. J Reflex : Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.
  • • Option A. J Reflex
  • • Option B. Cushing Reflex : Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.
  • • Option B. Cushing Reflex
  • • Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex : Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.
  • • Option C.
  • • Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text: Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true? (INICET MAY 2022) Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The true statements are:
  • • Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers provide widespread distribution throughout the body, innervating various organs and tissues. In contrast, parasympathetic fibers have a more restricted distribution, primarily targeting the head, neck, and trunk regions.
  • • Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
  • • Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. Motor neurons originate in the ventral horn of the spinal cord, and their axons branch out to innervate individual muscle fibers, facilitating voluntary muscle movements.
  • • Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 2: Incorrect. Sympathetic fibers do not travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain before synapsing. Instead, sympathetic preganglionic fibers travel a short distance to the ganglia (which are located close to the spinal cord) and then the postganglionic fibers travel a long distance to reach the effector organs.
  • • Statement 2:
  • • Statement 3: Incorrect. Parasympathetic fibers travel a long distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to or within the target organs.
  • • Statement 3:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to head neck and trunk

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High Glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: SA node release following in response to increasing blood pressure:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acetylcholine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors (pressure-sensitive receptors located in the carotid sinus and aortic arch) are activated. These receptors detect the rise in blood pressure and send signals to the cardiovascular center in the medulla oblongata, specifically to the cardio-inhibitory center (CIC). Activation of the CIC results in the stimulation of the vagus nerve, which releases acetylcholine at the SA node of the heart. Acetylcholine acts on muscarinic receptors to decrease the heart rate (a process known as bradycardia), helping to lower the blood pressure back to normal levels.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Norepinephrine : Norepinephrine is typically released in response to a decrease in blood pressure, not an increase. It is a sympathetic neurotransmitter that increases heart rate and contractility, which would raise blood pressure, not lower it.
  • • Option A. Norepinephrine
  • • Option B. Epinephrine : Similar to norepinephrine, epinephrine is released by the adrenal medulla in response to stress or low blood pressure. It increases heart rate, myocardial contractility, and peripheral vasoconstriction, which elevates blood pressure. Therefore, it is not released in response to increased blood pressure.
  • • Option B. Epinephrine
  • • Option C. Dopamine : Dopamine has various effects depending on the dose but is generally associated with increasing blood pressure and cardiac output. It is not involved in the reflex reduction of heart rate in response to high blood pressure.
  • • Option C. Dopamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetylcholine is released from the vagus nerve at the SA node in response to increased blood pressure, resulting in a decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) as part of the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The resection of the terminal ileum specifically compromises vitamin B12 absorption due to the loss of the primary site where the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is absorbed. This can lead to significant clinical issues related to vitamin B12 deficiency, such as anemia and neurological disturbances, unless managed with appropriate supplementation.
  • ➤ Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors
  • ➤ Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum Folate is absorbed in jejunum Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum
  • ➤ Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • ➤ Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

questions.text: Which of the following regulates the body temperature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The regulation of body temperature is primarily controlled by the hypothalamus. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for cooling mechanisms, akin to standing in front of an air conditioner during hot weather. Conversely, the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus manages warming mechanisms, similar to standing near an exhaust to receive warm air during cold weather.
  • • anterior nucleus
  • • cooling
  • • posterior nucleus
  • • warming
  • • This dual role in temperature regulation is unique to the hypothalamus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are involved in the coordination of movement and motor control, but they do not play a role in temperature regulation.
  • • Option B. Basal ganglia:
  • • Option C. Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, and does not regulate body temperature.
  • • Option C. Thalamus:
  • • Option D. Limbic system: The limbic system is involved in emotions, behavior, and long-term memory, but it does not have a role in the regulation of body temperature.
  • • Option D. Limbic system:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypothalamus, specifically its anterior and posterior nuclei, is responsible for regulating body temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inferior olivary nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus directly synapse onto Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, playing a pivotal role in motor control and learning processes.

questions.text: If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? ( INICET Nov 2021) ESV: End-systolic volume EDV: End-diastolic volume

options.label: A
options.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope

options.label: B
options.text: Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

options.label: C
options.text: End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope

options.label: D
options.text: Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.correct_answer: B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

questions.text: Which tongue papillae do not have taste buds? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Filiform

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds and are primarily involved in general sensations like touch and texture, not in the sensation of taste

questions.text: Baroreceptor provides? ( AIIMS Nov 2018
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Negative feedback

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Baroreceptors provide negative feedback to help maintain blood pressure within normal limits by triggering responses that counteract increases in blood pressure.

questions.text: Which ion channels are defective in CFTR gene mutation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cl-

questions.text: Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Forced expiration against an open glottis

Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction? ( INICET May 2020) Extracellular Ca 2+ is important for contraction Ca 2+ is released from mitochondria Ca 2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum Ligand-gated Ca 2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During skeletal muscle contraction, Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is essential for muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is mainly responsible for the resorption of divalent ions? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paracellular Transport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paracellular transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the main mechanism responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium, driven by the positive luminal charge and facilitated by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump and co-transporters.

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chest x-ray

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child presenting with shortness of breath on exertion and orthopnea, the first investigation should be a chest x-ray to evaluate potential pulmonary pathology and signs of congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of fine motor movement of fingers

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.correct_answer: C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.
  • • The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.
  • • These are:
  • • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.
  • • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.
  • • Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:
  • • Fine touch Tactile localization Tactile discrimination Vibration
  • • Fine touch
  • • Tactile localization
  • • Tactile discrimination
  • • Vibration
  • • This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.
  • • function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.
  • • Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception:
  • • Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.
  • • Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers:
  • • Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.
  • • Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)
  • ➤ I/L loss of Fine touch C/L loss of Pain & Temperature I/L loss of Proprioception I/L motor paralysis
  • ➤ I/L loss of Fine touch
  • ➤ C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • ➤ I/L loss of Proprioception
  • ➤ I/L motor paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following hormones uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling for cellular growth and angiogenesis? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VEGF (Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding that VEGF uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling specifically for promoting angiogenesis and vascular development, distinguishing it from other hormones that may use different signaling pathways or have different physiological roles.

questions.text: In which muscles are white fibers predominantly found? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • White fibers correspond to Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic muscle fibers. These fibers have high glycolytic capacity but low oxidative capacity. They are characterized by fast contraction speed, high myosin ATPase activity, and rapid fatigue. Hand muscles predominantly contain these white (Type IIB) fibers to facilitate precise, rapid movements required for fine motor skills.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a. Calf muscle : Calf muscles (particularly soleus) predominantly contain Type I and Type IIA fibers, which are red in color due to higher myoglobin content and greater capillary density. The soleus specifically is noted for containing Type IIA fibers (Fast Oxidative Glycolytic). Option b. Back muscles : Back muscles primarily contain Type I (Slow Oxidative) fibers that appear red due to high myoglobin content. These muscles are responsible for maintaining posture and require sustained contractions rather than rapid, powerful ones. Option c. Gluteal muscles : While gluteal muscles contain a mixture of fiber types, they don't predominantly feature white Type IIB fibers. They have a significant proportion of Type I and Type IIA fibers to support both postural maintenance and powerful movements.
  • • Option a. Calf muscle : Calf muscles (particularly soleus) predominantly contain Type I and Type IIA fibers, which are red in color due to higher myoglobin content and greater capillary density. The soleus specifically is noted for containing Type IIA fibers (Fast Oxidative Glycolytic).
  • • Option a. Calf muscle
  • • Option b. Back muscles : Back muscles primarily contain Type I (Slow Oxidative) fibers that appear red due to high myoglobin content. These muscles are responsible for maintaining posture and require sustained contractions rather than rapid, powerful ones.
  • • Option b. Back muscles
  • • Option c. Gluteal muscles : While gluteal muscles contain a mixture of fiber types, they don't predominantly feature white Type IIB fibers. They have a significant proportion of Type I and Type IIA fibers to support both postural maintenance and powerful movements.
  • • Option c. Gluteal muscles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic (white) muscle fibers predominate in hand muscles and other muscles requiring rapid, precise movements with short bursts of activity, reflecting their high glycolytic capacity, fast contraction speed, and quick fatigue properties.

questions.text: Maximum absorption of short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria occurs in the: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are primarily produced in the colon and absorbed from it. These 2-5 carbon weak acids have an average concentration of about 80 mmol/L in the colonic lumen, with acetate (60%), propionate (25%), and butyrate (15%) being the predominant types. They form through bacterial fermentation of complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber components that escape digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Stomach - The stomach primarily handles initial protein digestion and fat emulsification. The acidic environment is not conducive to the bacterial fermentation processes that generate SCFAs. Option B. Duodenum - The duodenum is involved in the early stages of nutrient digestion with pancreatic enzymes and bile, but not in SCFA production or absorption. Bacterial populations needed for SCFA production are minimal here. Option C. Jejunum - While the jejunum is a major site for nutrient absorption, it lacks the significant bacterial populations required for SCFA production. The relatively fast transit time also does not allow for substantial bacterial fermentation.
  • • Option A. Stomach - The stomach primarily handles initial protein digestion and fat emulsification. The acidic environment is not conducive to the bacterial fermentation processes that generate SCFAs.
  • • Option A. Stomach
  • • Option B. Duodenum - The duodenum is involved in the early stages of nutrient digestion with pancreatic enzymes and bile, but not in SCFA production or absorption. Bacterial populations needed for SCFA production are minimal here.
  • • Option B. Duodenum
  • • Option C. Jejunum - While the jejunum is a major site for nutrient absorption, it lacks the significant bacterial populations required for SCFA production. The relatively fast transit time also does not allow for substantial bacterial fermentation.
  • • Option C. Jejunum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SCFAs are unique among fatty acids in that they're produced by bacterial fermentation in the colon and represent an important source of energy for colonic epithelial cells, helping maintain mucosal integrity and acid-base balance.

questions.text: The value of TG and VLDL are high in chronic diabetes because of which of the following reasons: (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase

options.label: B
options.text: Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic diabetes, the combination of increased hormone sensitive lipase activity (due to low insulin levels) and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity leads to higher levels of triglycerides and VLDL. This reflects the central role of insulin in lipid metabolism regulation.

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? ( NICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exosome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Leydig cell

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.
  • • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function. The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads. LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.
  • • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function.
  • • The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • • LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads.
  • • LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sertoli cells : Incorrect as Sertoli cells are primarily involved in the nourishment and support of developing spermatozoa, not in the production of testosterone.
  • • Option B. Sertoli cells
  • • Option C. Seminiferous tubules : Incorrect because while these structures within the testes are involved in sperm production, the cells directly responsible for testosterone production are the Leydig cells, not the tubules themselves.
  • • Option C. Seminiferous tubules
  • • Option D. Epididymis : Incorrect as the epididymis is involved in the storage, maturation, and transport of sperm cells, not hormone production.
  • • Option D. Epididymis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells in the testes, which are specifically stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary gland. This hormonal production is crucial for male reproductive and general health.

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal insensible water loss is approximately 50 mL/hour, resulting from evaporation through the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pleuritis with/without pleural effusion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion stands out as the most frequent pulmonary complication in SLE due to the disease’s propensity to inflame serous membranes. Accurate diagnosis and effective management of SLE and its pulmonary manifestations are crucial for improving quality of life and reducing morbidity in affected patients.

questions.text: What is the stage of sleep denoted by the arrow: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) REM

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The stage of sleep indicated by the arrow is REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This can be identified based on the specific patterns observed in the EEG (Electroencephalogram), EMG (Electromyogram), and EOG (Electrooculogram) readings:
  • • EEG : The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves. EMG : The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams. EOG : The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.
  • • EEG : The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves.
  • • EEG
  • • EMG : The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams.
  • • EMG
  • • EOG : The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.
  • • EOG
  • • In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep stages (including NREM 2, 3, and 4) show different patterns:
  • • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns. Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep. Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.
  • • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns.
  • • Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep.
  • • Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. NREM 2 : This stage of sleep is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG, with reduced but not absent muscle tone and minimal eye movement. The patterns described in the question do not match this stage.
  • • Option A. NREM 2
  • • Option B. NREM 3 : Known as slow-wave sleep or deep sleep, NREM 3 is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. Muscle tone is decreased but not completely absent, and there is minimal to no eye movement. The pattern described does not correspond to NREM 3.
  • • Option B. NREM 3
  • • Option C. NREM 4 : Often combined with NREM 3 in the modern classification, this stage is also characterized by delta waves, reduced muscle tone, and lack of eye movement. The described pattern is inconsistent with this stage as well.
  • • Option C. NREM 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, high-frequency EEG waves, muscle atonia as shown in the EMG, and rapid eye movements as shown in the EOG. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for correctly identifying REM sleep, which is a critical stage for processes like memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is NOT directly measured in an ABG analysis? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Base excess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Base excess (BE) is not directly measured by the ABG machine but is calculated using the measured parameters. It represents the amount of strong acid or base needed to titrate blood to a pH of 7.40 at a PCO2 of 40 mmHg. The calculation involves pH, PCO2, and hemoglobin concentration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. PO2: The partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) is directly measured by the ABG machine using an oxygen electrode, providing immediate information about blood oxygenation.
  • • Option B. PO2:
  • • Option C. PCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) is directly measured using a Severinghaus electrode in the ABG machine, reflecting ventilation status.
  • • Option C. PCO2:
  • • Option D. pH: Blood pH is directly measured using a glass electrode in the ABG machine, indicating the hydrogen ion concentration.
  • • Option D. pH:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding that while ABG machines directly measure pH, PO2, and PCO2, other important parameters like base excess are derived through calculations using these measured values. This helps in comprehensive assessment of acid-base status.

questions.text: A 23-year-old hypertensive man comes to the hospital, on examination, BP was 150/90 mmHg, and was afebrile. On further evaluation, serum renin was found to be normal. He was diagnosed with Conn’s Syndrome. All are true about the Conn’s Syndrome except: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Conn’s Syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by the excessive secretion of aldosterone. Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to water retention, hypervolemia, and subsequently, hypertension. Additionally, aldosterone promotes the secretion of potassium and hydrogen ions via the renal tubules.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conn’s Syndrome is characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion leading to metabolic alkalosis, hypertension, and low renin levels.

questions.text: Calculate the net filtration pressure across the GFM for a patient with the data given below? ( AIIMS May 2018) Glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient = 6 Glomerular hydrostatic pressure =45 Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure =20 Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure =10 Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure =0
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 15 mmHg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The net filtration pressure (NFP) in the glomerulus, essential for kidney filtration, is calculated based on the differences between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures inside and outside the glomerular capillaries. In this scenario, an NFP of 15 mmHg favors the formation of urine by pushing fluid out of blood vessels into the Bowman's capsule.

questions.text: A lesion in which lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination?

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)

questions.text: During an 800-meter run (approximately 2 minutes), most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from? [Twisted PYQ]

questions.text: Inhibin is responsible for? (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarization, Repolarization, and hyperpolarization in a skeletal muscle action potential?( INICET May 2020) Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In skeletal muscle action potential, depolarization occurs due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, repolarization occurs due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, and hyperpolarization is caused by the prolonged efflux of K+.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors are responsible for tactile discrimination? ( INICET May 2021)

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of late proximal convoluted tubule except: [Twisted PYQ]

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels

options.label: B
options.text: Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

options.label: C
options.text: Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.correct_answer: B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.
  • • Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C : Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The dicrotic notch on the aortic pressure curve is caused by? (NEET PG 2017)

options.label: D
options.text: Rapid filling of the left ventricle

questions.correct_answer: C. Closing of the aortic valve
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The dicrotic notch is a small oscillation or wave that appears in the falling phase of the aortic pressure curve during the cardiac cycle. This notch is specifically caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve snaps shut. The dicrotic notch occurs at the end of ventricular systole when the aortic pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure, causing the aortic valve to close. This closure creates a brief backward movement of blood and subsequent rebound, generating the characteristic notch in the aortic pressure tracing.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Closing of the mitral valve The mitral valve closes at the beginning of ventricular systole, not during the falling phase of aortic pressure. Mitral valve closure contributes to the first heart sound (S1) and occurs before ejection of blood into the aorta, so it cannot be responsible for the dicrotic notch. Option B. Closing of the tricuspid valve The tricuspid valve closes at the beginning of right ventricular systole, similar to mitral valve closure. It has no direct effect on aortic pressure and occurs much earlier in the cardiac cycle than the dicrotic notch. Option D. Rapid filling of the left ventricle Rapid filling of the left ventricle occurs during early diastole, after the aortic valve has closed. This ventricular filling phase follows the dicrotic notch rather than causing it, making this option incorrect.
  • • Option A. Closing of the mitral valve The mitral valve closes at the beginning of ventricular systole, not during the falling phase of aortic pressure. Mitral valve closure contributes to the first heart sound (S1) and occurs before ejection of blood into the aorta, so it cannot be responsible for the dicrotic notch.
  • • Option A. Closing of the mitral valve
  • • Option B. Closing of the tricuspid valve The tricuspid valve closes at the beginning of right ventricular systole, similar to mitral valve closure. It has no direct effect on aortic pressure and occurs much earlier in the cardiac cycle than the dicrotic notch.
  • • Option B. Closing of the tricuspid valve
  • • Option D. Rapid filling of the left ventricle Rapid filling of the left ventricle occurs during early diastole, after the aortic valve has closed. This ventricular filling phase follows the dicrotic notch rather than causing it, making this option incorrect.
  • • Option D. Rapid filling of the left ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The dicrotic notch is a distinctive feature on the aortic pressure curve that specifically marks the moment of aortic valve closure at the end of ventricular systole, representing the transition between systole and diastole.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with involuntary dancing movements of his right hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatic fever. What constitutes the ganglia involved in the presenting complication? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Caudate nucleus and putamen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ganglia involved in Sydenham chorea, associated with rheumatic fever, are the caudate nucleus and putamen, which are part of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mechanically

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically, meaning their interaction and functional coupling rely on direct physical contacts between these protein structures to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.text: What is the function of Tubuloglomerular feedback? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Regulate GFR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubuloglomerular feedback is an adaptive mechanism in the kidneys that helps regulate GFR in response to changes in blood pressure and filtrate flow rate, ensuring stable renal function and homeostasis.

questions.text: A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022) LES is open and UES is closed. Strong contractions in the stomach. Inspiration against a closed glottis. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter. LES opens and UES opens. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine. LES: Lower esophageal sphincter UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sequence of events in act of vomiting:
  • ➤ Sequence of events in act of vomiting:
  • ➤ Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing Closure of glottis Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone Elevation of soft palate Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.
  • ➤ Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  • ➤ Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  • ➤ Closure of glottis
  • ➤ Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  • ➤ Elevation of soft palate
  • ➤ Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  • ➤ Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  • ➤ Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  • ➤ Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with an unconscious state. An arterial blood analysis reveals the following values: pH = 7.1; PCO2 = 22 mmHg; HCO3- = 16 mEq/l. Identify the patient’s condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of metabolic acidosis, both the pH and bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels are decreased, and the respiratory system may compensate by lowering PCO2.

questions.text: Arrange the sequence of evets occurring after p wave in ECG? ( INICET May 2020) a wave in JVP First heart sound Rapid filling of ventricles T wave in ECG
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The sequence of events following the P wave in an ECG is: a wave in JVP, first heart sound, T wave, and then rapid filling of ventricles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with narcolepsy is prescribed modafinil for excessive daytime sleepiness. What is the primary mechanism of action of modafinil in promoting wakefulness? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: B
options.text: Increases dopamine availability in synaptic cleft

questions.correct_answer: B. Increases dopamine availability in synaptic cleft
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increases dopamine availability in synaptic cleft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the mechanism of action of wake-promoting medications, specifically how modafinil promotes wakefulness through dopaminergic pathways rather than through adenosine blockade like caffeine.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serotonin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.
  • • Gastric Acid Secretion:
  • • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl). Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.
  • • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • • Parietal Cells:
  • • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.
  • • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells:
  • • Stimulation of ECL Cells:
  • • Stimulation of ECL Cells:
  • • Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.
  • • Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  • • Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  • • Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.
  • • Role of Serotonin:
  • • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.
  • • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.
  • • Serotonin:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option A. Gastrin:
  • • Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option B. Histamine:
  • • Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.
  • • Option C. Acetylcholine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

questions.text: Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: ( INICET Nov 2022) Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels Repolarizing K+ currents Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:
  • ➤ The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:
  • ➤ C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  • ➤ D. Transient outward flow of potassium
  • ➤ A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  • ➤ B. Repolarizing K+ currents
